title: Beef Bulgogi with Lettuce Wraps
description: Thinly sliced marinated beef seared quickly for caramelized edges and tender bite, served with crisp lettuce cups and bright accompaniments. Sweet-savory-sesame flavors with garlic, ginger and scallions make quick handheld wraps perfect for weeknight dinners or entertaining.

ingredients.notes: very thin slices, about 2–3 mm; partially freeze for easier slicing if needed
can substitute brown sugar for deeper flavor

ingredients.display_name: ripe Asian pear (or Bosc pear), grated

ingredients.notes: toasted sesame oil for best flavor
white and green parts, sliced on bias

ingredients.display_name: mirin or rice wine (optional but recommended)

ingredients.notes: neutral oil with high smoke point

ingredients.display_name: butter lettuce or bibb lettuce leaves, washed and separated
ingredients.notes: choose large intact leaves for wrapping
serve on side for non-wrap eaters

ingredients.display_name: gochujang (Korean chili paste) or ssamjang for dipping

ingredients.notes: for seasoning vegetables and rice if used

ingredients.display_name: fresh cilantro or perilla leaves (optional garnish)
ingredients.notes: perilla (kkaennip) if available for authentic flavor

steps.text: Slice or prepare the beef thinly and place in a large bowl; pat dry any excess moisture for better sear.
In a separate bowl combine soy sauce, sugar, grated pear, minced garlic, grated ginger, sesame oil, sliced scallions and mirin if using; whisk until sugar dissolves to make the marinade.
Pour the marinade over the beef, toss thoroughly to coat, cover and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes and up to 4 hours; short marination is fine for very thin slices.
While meat marinates, prepare vegetables: separate and dry lettuce leaves, julienne carrot and cucumber, and set out sesame seeds and condiments.
Heat a large heavy skillet or cast-iron pan over high heat until shimmering, add vegetable oil and when hot spread beef in a single layer (work in batches to avoid steaming).

Sear beef without moving for 30–45 seconds to develop a crust, then stir or toss and continue cooking another 30–60 seconds until just cooked through and caramelized; remove to a plate and repeat with remaining beef.
Taste a piece and adjust seasoning with a pinch of salt or additional soy if needed; sprinkle toasted sesame seeds and extra sliced scallions over the cooked beef.
Assemble wraps by placing a portion of beef into a lettuce leaf, topping with julienned vegetables, a dab of gochujang or ssamjang if desired, and garnish with cilantro or perilla; serve immediately.
